comment:
★★★½
Watched by Jeremy Crabb 21 Feb 2016
1
Though it falls into some big cliches, and is very predictable, Zootopia touches on some issues in society that needed to be discussed at this point in time, and it is beautifully animated. The voice talent is all great, and the two lead characters are very likable, though not incredibly memorable. It has some great humor as well, and I can't deny that I had fun with it. Though it may be very formulaic, Zootopia is very fun and it has the balls to address issues that should be addressed and discussed, so I must give it credit for that.
GRADE: B

comment:
★★★★ Watched by Ralph 21 Feb 2016
Animation is not a genre and should not be stereotyped as for kids only. Disney's Zootopia cleverly conveys that and more as it goes beyond the usual "follow your dreams" by dealing with social issues such as prejudice, discrimination, and stereotypes. The result? A complex mystery film with two unlikely friends learning from life's mistakes as they discover more about society through each other's eyes. Their journey serves as a social commentary on how an individual's worth can be unfairly ignored. They stood up against hasty generalizations and ultimately showed us that there can be unity in diversity.

comment:
★★★★
Watched by Mark James Atienza 21 Feb 2016
Relishing a creative sense of imagination visually, "Zootopia" creates an appealing animated world (through the Animal Kingdom) that successfully emphasized its message about diversity. Even with its plotting and characterizations it triumphed, featuring mortal enemies as allies and turning seemingly-innocent ones as villains. A bold statement indeed, and it knows how to tinker with it: wrapping it up on a crime/mystery thriller vibe and well-crafted sense of humor. The only problem was its emotional baggage that gets wearily imposed but still, this animated feature rocks.

comment:
★★★★ Watched by Erika 22 Feb 2016
5
Disney's Zootopia is a real treat. I was incredibly disappointed with Disney's previous movies Frozen and Big Hero 6, they just felt average and they didn't stick with me at all. But that's not the case with Zootopia, this movie was a ton of fun. Disney’s previous two movies used tragedies as important plot points or even as plot devices. Zootopias emotional core is used to show character development and to get its surprisingly mature messages across. The emotion in this movie is effective and never feels forced. Zootopia is a fast, fun, funny, beautiful and mature animated film which is Disney’s best film in years.

Another win for Disney!

★★★★½
Watched by Njabs Phungula 27 Feb 2016

The film's referential nature is something I would expect from Dreamworks but, surprisingly, it works well here. Zootropolis has so much going on but it manages to tie everything together with no difficulty. The film is examines racism in a way that is accessible to kids (I sincerely hope that the younger ones will be able to make the connection). In typical Disney fashion, the film has a lot of heart but is also extremely hilarious. I loved the voice cast, the score, and the overall fun nature of the film. I only wish they'd done away with Gazelle's (Shakira) big number at the end.

comment:
★★★★ Watched by SidneyLumetSuxx 03 Mar 2016
One of the most family-friendly animated flicks in recent memory. When I say "the most family-friendly", I mean both adults and kids can get equal amount of entertainment and value from it.
Zootopia is social commentary that both adults and kids can pick up on but in their own ways. Themes of inclusion//seclusion, prejudice//racism//sexism, et cetera. Remarkably, it's somehow not preachy. On top of all that the film is also just terrifically animated and hilariously directed and realistically written.
Def worth a watch. Def gonna watch again. Def gonna own one day. Def gonna be the animated film of the year.

Disney at its edgiest.

★★★★½
Watched by ryan 04 Mar 2016
Disney's "Fuck you" to Donald Trump and his supporters.
This is an example of committee filmmaking done absolutely right. Zootopia is stuffed to the brim with visual metaphors, amazingly detailed environments, and beautifully animated characters. The casting is excellent (especially Jason Bateman's fox and J.K. Simmons's lion), the writing is witty. It's a classic approach, using anthropomorphized animals to tell a relevant political parable. It may be wholly unsubtle with its themes, but those themes are as prescient as ever, and sometimes people need messages to be overt in order for them sink in.

Cute, gorgeously animated, and very funny; but it also surprisingly touches on some very adult themes and political issues that are pretty uncommon to hear in children's films.
It's a lot smarter and more ambitious than I was expecting it to be; and some may feel that some of it comes off as too forced, but I mostly found it to be refreshing to see an animated film go for a more adult approach in it's storytelling while still being funny and entertaining from start to finish.
It's a great family movie with great morals, beautiful animation, smart writing, and timely adult themes.
Don't miss it.

Watched by Tom Samaroden 04 Mar 2016
Super fun Disney film with a heavier message than usual. Zootopia is probably the cutest film I've seen to tackle racism issues, and though the film ends happily for all involved (this film is a Disney movie after all), the attempt to even take about issues of judging others based solely on where they came from should be respected. The film is ultimately too cute to actually solve and give means of fixing these problems for adults, but if children start learning about the problem and coming up with solutions, then maybe prejudices, in a generation or two, could be a thing of the past.

"Ice him!"

What a pleasant surprise this turned out to be.

With a new Disney renaissance that didn't take a single wrong step yet, Zootopia is more of a small lump. And dare I say, unnecessary.

I guess the studio is putting more effort on Moana.

Zootopia is clever, witty, charming, funny and very entertaining. This is without a doubt one the best animated films in recent memory and it might just be my favorite. While I love The Lego Movie, I'm debating if I liked Zootopia even more and that's saying something. comment:
★★★★
Watched by Jeff MacIver 06 Mar 2016
The animals in Zootopia come across largely as well-formed characters, which is a huge achievement. By tackling the idea of animal stereotypes head on, we get a little peek into how complicated those behavioral short-cuts can be.
There is more than a little reliance on the classic tropes for sake of jokes, thought. The population of the bunny town is shown on a sign with the numbers going up by the second, etc. But by and large, pre-judgements are called into question at every turn.
Very enjoyable. And even better, very light on dumb humor.

comment:
★★★ Watched by Max Christensen 05 Mar 2016
Underneath the familiar buddy cop story and predictable mystery is an impressively deft commentary on race. And beyond that, is an even subtler commentary on gender. It's great to see a Disney heroine who doesn't need romance, who excels in a male-dominated police force, and who demonstrates the reward of hard work and hope.
The main characters are fun to watch, there are some fun gags with the world, and the final act is handled really well. I'd recommend it.

This wants to be all different kinds of funny and thoughtful. Wacky funny, smart funny, cultural reference funny, slapstick funny, kid funny, adult funny. Culturally thoughtful, emotionally thoughtful, progressively thoughtful, Orwellian thoughtful. It wants to, in the words of its siren call theme song, "try everything." It is mass-market idealistic progressivism for a society that hates and relies on capitalism more every year. But then again, it's for kids right? You have to dumb all this *real* stuff down in order for kids to get it. There's no way they're going to understand how it really works!

comment:
★★★½ Watched by Carlos Chiriboga 08 Mar 2016

comment:
★★★★
Watched by KISSman 04 Mar 2016
For a company who was founded on animals behaving like people, Zootopia is a surprisingly rare offering by Disney where every single character in the film is non-human -- and more importantly, not a princess! Sure Zootopia is a great animated feature, but its bold underlying message about stereotyping, discrimination and racism is what makes Zootopia so much more than just a cheery little movie about animals. I don't know if an animated movie has ever felt more timely than this one and you can't help but hope that the themes presented here will resonate with kids beyond the theater.

Well-animated and thoroughly engaging. It serves as a solid racism allegory for kids, and I particularly appreciate how it highlights the ability of a demagogue to exploit racial tensions to further his/her own aims. Digging too deeply reveals flaws in the allegory, but I'm not sure it's important for it to be flawless for its target demographic to learn something. It does have a more serious flaw, in that the writers seem to hit a wall about two thirds of the way through the film, and requires a development to come out of nowhere in order to get it moving forwards again.

This is French Connection meets Taxi with a slight stop at a Quarantine type horror movie done by Walt Disney (Feature) Animation. On paper it may sound like a weird combo but, but Zootopia is able to make it work. It is a much more light-hearted movie than the last two Disney Animated movies (Frozen and Big Hero 6.) Zootopia is a great action comedy cop-drama and I dare say is more for adults with these in-jokes than the kids. For where this movie ranks, it is nearly as good as Big Hero 6 but is better than Frozen.

comment:
★★★½
Watched by Nathan Jongewaard 13 Mar 2016
Some of the best character animation I've ever seen. A charming way of teaching a lesson about prejudice—but must ALL kids' movies teach lessons? Particularly when such machinations seem to distract the (7!) writers from creating an organic story not overly beholden to plot mechanics?
Still, there is much to enjoy and admire here. I just wish the economics of such films allowed for greater realism, even in a story about talking animals.

Great story, beautiful animation, a real Disney feel to the whole thing. Lots of laughs and lots of feels.
